variant.question: In error the V1 used on a particular take-off exceeds the correct value of V1. If an engine fails at a speed immediately above the correct value of V1 then...

options.text: the increased airspeed may lead to over&rotation.
the one engine inoperative take-off distance may exceed the take-off distance available.
the accelerate stop distance may exceed the accelerate stop distance available.
V1 may be too high resulting in the initial climb performance decreasing.

variant.question: The 2 seconds time interval during take-off between VEF and V1 is used for:

options.text: calling ATC.
deciding (continue or abort).
informing the cabin.
recognition.

variant.question: During take-off, the time between critical engine failure and V1 (recognition time) is assumed to be approximately:

options.text: 2 seconds.
5 seconds.
6 seconds.
0 seconds.

variant.question:
Which of the following will affect the level-off altitude during a drift-down?

1) outside air temperature   
2) wind   
3) distance to alternate airport   
4) engine thrust

A pilot is operating his first flight on a longer variant of an aircraft type he currently flies. Due to the increased risk of a tailstrike, pilot decides to rotate at a slower (but still acceptable) rate. This will have an effect on (1) \_\_\_\_\_ TOR, (2) \_\_\_\_\_ TOD and (3) \_\_\_\_\_ climb gradient.

options.text: (1) Decreased; (2) Decreased; (3) Decreased
(1) Increased; (2) Increased; (3) Increased
(1) Decreased; (2) Increased; (3) Decreased
(1) Increased; (2) Decreased; (3) Increased

variant.question: If bleed-air systems are used during take-off, the take-off distance is...

options.text: decreased, as more fuel is burnt.
decreased, due to the lower acceleration.
increased, as less thrust is available.
the same, as it does not on impact engine performance.

variant.question: Assuming an engine failure during take-off. An increase of V**1** will (1) \_\_\_\_\_ TOM limited by TODA and will (2) \_\_\_\_\_ TOM limited by ASDA.

options.text: (1) not be affect; (2) increase
(1) decrease; (2) increase
(1) increase; (2) decrease
(1) not be affect; (2) decrease

variant.question:
After calculating the following take-off figures, what would be the consequence of the pilots accidentally entering a V**1** value of 124 kt.

V**1**: 142 kt   
 V**R**: 142 kt   
 V**2**: 145 kt

options.text: TOD would decrease significantly and the aircraft might not be able to get airborne before the end of the runway in case of engine failure.
TOD would increase significantly and the aircraft may not become airborne before the end of the runway in case of an engine failure.
TOD is not affected and the aircraft will not encounter any additional challenges in becoming airborne before the end of the runway in case of an engine failure.
TOD is not affected though the aircraft may not become airborne before the end of the runway in case of an engine failure.

variant.question:
Following a take-off calculation, a range of decision speeds is found to be available with a maximum V**1** of 150 kt and a minimum V**1** of 142 kt.  
In the event of an engine failure after the chosen V**1**, which of the following statements would be correct?

options.text: Using a V1 of 150 kt compared to 142 kt will reduce the take-off distance and leave the climb performance unchanged.
Using a V1 of 150 kt compared to 142 kt will reduce the take-off distance and improve the climb performance.
Using a V1 of 142 kt compared to 150 kt will reduce the take-off distance and leave the climb performance unchanged.
Using a V1 of 142 kt compared to 150 kt will reduce the take-off distance and degrade the climb performance.
